awd_titl_txt: Impact of Ion Transport and Dissociation on Polymer Electrolyte Battery Rate Capability
awd_abstract_narration:
Solid, polymer electrolytes are needed to enable transformative increases in battery capacity for advanced electric and hybrid-electric transportation applications. However, the current polymer electrolytes suffer from low ion transport rates, most commonly characterized by conductivity. This fundamental engineering science project will evaluate the hypothesis that conductivity alone is not a good metric for battery rate capability and that an equally critical component is ion transport in the polymer electrolytes. Such understanding will allow intelligent design of the next generation of solid electrolytes for electric vehicle batteries. Novel polymer electrolytes will be studied with experimental techniques not typically applied to electrolytes. The techniques provide direct measurement of ion concentration in real time and ion speciation, both of which are important for accurate and complete characterization of polymer electrolyte performance in a battery. The investigators of this project combine complementary expertise in engineering and chemistry, respectively, which will be used to further the understanding of ion-transport and battery performance through cutting-edge, time-resolved measurements and new synthetic polyelectrolytes tailored to probe structure-property relationships in these systems. For educational and outreach activities, this project includes hands-on battery activities related to this research that will be presented at economically disadvantaged middle schools. Students involved in this research will be trained with skills needed in the synthetic development of new precision polyelectrolyte systems and commercial development of lithium batteries. 

The goal of this research is to develop a complete picture of transport in polymer electrolytes and how it connects to battery performance. The specific aims are (1) to fully characterize transport in a systematic set of polymer electrolytes using several complementary techniques, (2) to investigate the role of ion speciation and electrolyte structure on transport behavior, and (3) to determine limiting currents for polymer-electrolyte batteries and compare to rate predictions based on a complete understanding of transport. Physical insight into the underpinnings of transport will be achieved using surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy to evaluate dissociation state and x-ray scattering to examine the connectivity of ionic structure. This work will be conducted on the current standard polymer electrolyte, poly(ethylene oxide) (PEO) containing lithium bis-trifluoromethanesulfonimide (LiTFSI) salt. The effect of nanostructure will be examined using a mechanically strong PEO-containing block copolymer with LiTFSI. Precision polyelectrolytes blended with PEO will be used to draw conclusions about the effect of anion connectivity on dissociation state and its commensurability with the cation structure. Finally, limiting currents of polymer electrolyte batteries will be measured and predicted with continuum-level simulations. This project encompasses a thorough evaluation of transport in polymer electrolytes for lithium batteries which could shift the paradigm in understanding what limits the discharge rate in these batteries. Knowledge will be gained of the physical underpinnings of transport using a combination of frontier techniques and novel materials. A validated polymer electrolyte battery model will be developed and made publicly available. It will assist the battery community in determining target transport properties for the next generation of solid electrolytes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

The goals of this project were to develop a complete picture of transport in polymer electrolytes and connect ion transport to battery performance. Custom experimental techniques were developed and used to measure lithium salt diffusion in a polyether as a function of concentration, and the data was analyzed with a numerical model that was developed by project personnel.[10.1021/acs.jpcb.9b11446] The ability of the polyether to dissociate lithium ions from anions was also examined with the custom (infrared spectroscopy) technique, and results were interpreted with the aid of simulations from a collaborator.[10.3389/fenrg.2020.569442] The foundational work to develop techniques and models was conducted on a standard polymer electrolyte that has been well studied.

The most pioneering aspects of the work then applied these and other methods to novel precision single-ion conductors (SIC) that were synthesized by the co-PI (Kennemur) and blended by the PI (Hallinan) with poly(ethylene oxide) (PEO) for numerous phase miscibility, transport, and electrochemical measurements. The general schematic representation of these materials is presented in Figure 1. The precision SIC mirrors poly(styrene sulfonate) (PSS) a commonly used polyanion, but has increased yet precise ion distance. The effect of increased ion spacing results in miscibility with PEO that is not observed with PS analogues and higher lithium ion conductivity than has previously been observed in a polymer blend electrolyte.[10.1002/macp.202100269 and 10.1039/D2PY00605G] Other advantages are that the glass transition temperature (Tg) of these SICs are significantly lower than those of PSS analogs, and these materials provided new answers towards blend behavior, such a miscibility, and ion transport as function of these enhanced chain dynamics at varying temperatures and compositions.

This project completed a thorough evaluation of transport in polymer electrolytes for lithium batteries which is crucial knowledge for understanding what limits the discharge rate in these batteries. Two types of blends have been examined, one with weak ion correlations and one with strong correlations. As shown in Figure 2, this affects the miscibility of the blends, but both are miscible at most compositions. The highest lithium ion conductivity was found to be in the 50-50 blend of PEO with the polyanion with strong ion correlation. In the miscibility gap, clear indications of phase separation were observed visually, from blend Tg, and from noise in conductivity measurements. The most promising blend composition has been used successfully in a lab-scale lithium battery. Due to the promising performance of the precision TFSI SIC and of these blends, two provisional patent applications have been filed.

The two types of polymer blend electrolytes yield interesting results individually. However, together they provide additional insight into the thermodynamics of the blends. The observed behavior has been predicted by simulations that show that ion correlations enhance polymer blend miscibility.[10.1021/mz400511r] If ion correlations are weak, then enhancement of miscibility occurs at all compositions, but if ion correlations are strong then miscibility enhancement only occurs in the concentrated polyelectrolyte regime and a miscibility gap appears in the dilute polyelectrolyte regime. This correspondence between experiment and simulation is exciting, but complete understanding of why one blend exhibited weak ion correlation while the other exhibited strong ion correlation requires future work.

Broader Impacts

Lithium batteries are an important part of sustainable energy storage, but innovation in solid electrolytes is needed to improve safety, durability, and performance. Polymers are essential due to their ability to be easily processed, but ion mobility is quite limited in polymer electrolytes, which limits the rate that the battery can be charged. This research has contributed to intelligent design of the next generation of solid electrolytes for electric vehicle batteries by developing frontier techniques and studying novel polymer electrolytes. This research developed a new type of polymer electrolyte that can selectively transport lithium ions, greatly improving charging rate. The material is a blend of a precision polyanion, that is a polymer with negatively charged ions dangling regularly from the chain, and a polyether, a polymer containing many oxygen atoms in the backbone that facilitate the dissociation of lithium ions from the polyanion. The investigators of this project, who combine complementary expertise in engineering and chemistry, mentored 4 PhD students (2 female, 2 graduated) and 1 postdoctoral scholar in multidisciplinary research. Through collaborations with Oak Ridge National Lab, Argonne National Lab, the University of Pennsylvania, and locally, 12 other graduate students were impacted by this project. Seventeen undergraduate students have been involved in this project, 12 from groups underrepresented in STEM, 11 as authors on publications, and 7 who decided to go on to graduate school. Through the FAMU-FSU College of Engineering, a diverse swath of thousands of area residents has been exposed to hands-on battery activities. In addition to 17 publications related to the project, 2 patent applications have been filed. This project has resulted in 28 presentations (14 invited), 2 webinars, and 6 courses taught.


Last Modified: 05/01/2023
Modified by: Daniel Hallinan

Images (1 of )
  • Figure 1. Schematics of general materials approach to polymers studied as lithium battery electrolytes in this work from (left) the control materials, (center) the novel polyanion, to (right) the material processing approach to achieve record-breaking performance.
    Daniel T. Hallinan Jr.
    Copyright owner is an institution with an existing agreement allowing use by NSF
    Daniel Hallinan
    Figure 1 - Polymer Electrolyte Schematics
  • Figure 2. Schematic representation of temperature-composition phase diagrams of neutral polymer blend and polymer blend electrolytes adapted from literature simulation. In the shaded regions the blend will separate into two phases. Data points represent experimental observations from our work.
    Daniel T. Hallinan Jr.
    Copyright owner is an institution with an existing agreement allowing use by NSF
    Daniel Hallinan
    Figure 2 - Polymer Blend Phase Diagram Schematics
